work.p: The two sentences of this manuscript appeared in slightly different forms in the prose preface to the 1855 first edition of Leaves of Grass.

titleStmt.title: Why need genius
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

notesStmt.note: The content of this manuscript, which is known only from a transcription published by Richard Maurice Bucke in Notes and Fragments (London, Ontario: A. Talbot & Co., printers, 1899), 103, appeared in slightly revised form in the prose preface to the 1855 first edition of Leaves of Grass. The date of composition is therefore most probably the early 1850s.

biblStruct.note: Grier derives this text from Notes & Fragments, ed. Richard Maurice Bucke (London, Ontario: A. Talbot & Co., printers, 1899), 103.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Why need genius
bibl.orgName: The location of this manuscript is unknown.

revisionDesc.change: reconciled with EAD record; added Work ID

body.p: Why need genius and the people of These States be demeaned to romances? Let facts and histories be properly told, there is no more need of romances.
